Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Acoustics Lab on a Chip for Comprehensive Biophysical Studies of Tumor Cells: Towards Personalized Cancer Diagnosis and Therapeutics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The main objective of this CAREER proposal is to develop surface acoustic wave devices along with the associated chemical and biological sensors to study the bio-mechanical properties of cells and its relationship to disease. Acoustic waves applied at the cellular level can be used to elucidate biophysical properties of cells and reveal diagnostic as well as therapeutic signatures with accuracy and sensitivity that are not possible to attain in current technologies. The research objective of this CAREER proposal is to test this hypothesis in three steps: 1.Design, develop and characterize a monolithic cell biology lab-on-a-chip (LOC) integrated with novel magnetic cell capture and surface acoustic wave (SAW) transducers, 2.Study and evaluate the efficacy of SAWs for non-invasive, contactless sonoporation and transfection studies on tumor cells and identify the unique acoustic signature of each cell type for disease diagnostics, therapeutics as well as drug screening tests, 3.Carry out systematic studies of cell biomechanical properties as a function of disease type and state on a CMOS Acoustic LOC with integrated microfluidics and on chip electronics.
Intellectual Merit: Quantitatively understanding the mechanical properties of cells and their relationship to the cells health may provide a method to elegantly differentiate between cells without using chemical sensing techniques that may require alteration of their biochemical state. These studies can transform the current state of medicine and potentially enable the in-situ capture and destruction of circulating tumor cells hence obliterating the metastasis phenomenon. In addition, this project will produce novel resources in sharing knowledge and collaboration of researchers in the fields of electrical, biomedical engineering, molecular biology, biochemistry and cancer pathology. In particular, new knowledge and science will be disseminated in cancer diagnosis and therapy, cellular mechanotransduction, mechanobiology, microfabrication, acoustic wave devices and integrated electronics.
Broader Impacts: Proposed multidisciplinary project is expected to transform the engineering and life sciences education at University of Miami (UM) and integrate educational activities and cutting-edge research. The PI envisions a transformational effect on the training of next generation engineers and scientists in the discipline transcending fields of bionanotechnology, MEMS and VLSI. With over 25% of the students being of Hispanic descent, UM is proud to be ranked 1st among universities serving Hispanics in the United States. In addition, College of Engineering is ranked 15th in the nation for the percentage of women who were awarded a B.S. in engineering. This remarkable diversity is reflected in the student members of the PI's research group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Onur Tigli completed the research funded by the NSF CAREER program titled "Acoustics Lab on a Chip for Comprehensive Biophysical Studies of Tumor Cells: Towards Personalized Cancer Diagnosis and Therapeutics." This project investigated the development and integration of several proprietary technologies to be used as a microchip based hand-held platform for cancer diagnosis and therapeutics with single cell precision. The final platform not only allows a small form-factor, standalone device that eliminates external large electronics equipment but also provides easy-to-use, plug-and-play, replaceable mass producible customized microchips that are integrating microfluidics and electronics. These microchips employ three novel technologies that were developed according to the proposed tasks: 1. Surface acoustic wave devices for sensing and sonoporation 2. Electromagnetic devices for viable cell capture and release 3. Electrical devices for characterization and cell enumeration. This lab-on-a-chip platform greatly improves device (re)usability, experiment repeatability, and enhances data collection process and data quality.

As a result of this research, Dr. Tigli, the members of his lab and their collaborators collectively produced 12 journal publications. In addition, the findings of the project also resulted in a total of 12 conference presentations. With this funding, Dr. Tigli was able to supervise 3 PhD Dissertations and 1 MS Thesis work. This project also resulted in 1 provisional patent application.

Successful outcomes of educational objectives of the project allowed the training of next generation engineers through the initial development and annual improvement of 3 brand new courses. With the addition of rosters for these courses, a cumulative of 83 undergraduate and 30 graduate students were trained during the educational activities throughout the life of the project. In addition, a total of 6 PhD, 2 Master's, 6 undergraduate and 1 high school students were involved directly in the research activities and outcomes of the project. Dr. Tigli established productive collaborations with a total of 12 scientists with varying expertise and seniority (professors, clinicians, post-doc associates and graduate researchers). 

For broader impact, variety of outreach venues were explored. Specifically, Dr. Tigli and the members of his lab collectively attended 8 conferences and symposia at 3 local, 4 national, and 1 international destination where dissemination of their findings were made possible. As a part of the broader impact and outreach plans, Dr. Tigli and his team developed 4 short educational videos on several engineering topics relating to the research outcomes of this grant. These original content videos were produced using in-house equipment and software to record and edit the interviews in addition to developing the animations and presentations. The resulting videos were disseminated to the national scientific community through features at NSF Science 360 website. In addition, the same videos were also published on the University of Miami Youtube site for the internal dissemination to the broader student body of the University as well as to the international scientific community. As a result of these outreach activities, 6 online and 1 print media articles and cover stories were published about Dr. Tigli's lab and his NSF funded research activities. In order to inform the general public, broader scientific community at the university, students and peers at the college, Dr. Tigli delivered 12 seminars at 6 distinct venues. For one of these events, Dr. Tigli delivered a seminar at the Miami Science Museum that reached out directly to local community -ages ranging 5 to 70- and educated the general public on innovation at the micro and nano scale. At this event, Dr. Tigli's research team also developed an interactive exhibition stand and demonstrated working devices from their research.

All these outcomes present great potential to inform new technologies while addressing important challenges and pressing needs in healthcare industry. More specifically, the versatility of the produced platform can target numerous applications in broader field of medicine where cutting-edge research in personalized or precision medicine are expected to pay large dividends in point-of-care and clinical use cases. Therefore, the achieved project outcomes are expected to have a significant impact on the economics of healthcare and enhance public knowledge and awareness on the use of technological innovation and scientific research for the betterment of human life. They can also potentially create awareness about the importance of early diagnosis and continued monitoring of diseases like cancer using novel technologies like the ones that were developed in this project. Furthermore, it can provide a smart, high-throughput platform to engineers, researchers, clinicians, academics, manufacturing, biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries for accelerating the development of novel testing and therapeutics modalities for diseases that will appear in the future. This possibility can undoubtedly help improve the national and global medical infrastructure while serving as a model to overcome the detriments caused by diseases like cancer.

The details of the results are made available to public at http://tigli.coe.miami.edu
